#Text=Goslar
#Text=Goslar
#Text=is a medieval town in Lower Saxony and serves as a regional hub to the wider Harz area .
#Text=It lies at the foot of the Harz Mountains ( highest elevation 3,744 feet ) .
#Text=Goslar is situated some 150 Miles West of Berlin .
#Text=The nearest cities are Brunswick , Hanover , and Magdeburg .
#Text=Goslar is much older than Berlin and worth a visit .
#Text=If you are interested in history , outdoor pursuits ( especially hiking ) , tranquility and nature , then Goslar is the right spot for you .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Goslar was founded in 922 AD , although it is widely assumed that there had been a settlement since pre-Roman times .

#Text=The town is famed for its magnificent gates and ramparts , the medieval Imperial Palace , Romanesque churches , its half timbered guild houses , the ancient Rammelsberg ore mine ... and its witches , the last of which was burned at the stake in 1657 AD .
#Text=In medieval times the city was a major producer of armouries and coins — the raw ores for their manufacture came from the Rammelsberg mine just outside the city 's walls .
#Text=History
#Text=What , Ram + Goat = Goslar ?
#Text=Not quite ... !
#Text=According to legend , Ramm , a knight to Henry 's son Otto the Great , tied his horse to a tree , half way up the Rammelsberg , to continue hunting in the undergrowth .
#Text=In anticipation of the return of its owner , the horse scraped with its hoof in the ground laying open a ledge of silver so rich that it took over a millennium to mine .
#Text=Hence the mountain and mine were called the Rammelsberg , after Otto 's knight Ramm .
#Text=As the wife of knight Ramm was called Gosa , they named the town Goslar in her honor .
#Text=Emperors , Dukes , and Townsfolk

#Text=Essentially Goslar was a Free Imperial City , which was under direct control of the Emperor and there were no regional feudal overlords , who were in charge of the city until the end of the Thirty 's Year War .
#Text=Thus the citizens were largely left to their own devices , since the emperors had mostly better things to do than to sit in their Imperial Palace at Goslar .
#Text=There were several other imperial palaces throughout the Holy Roman Empire , where the emperors held court .
#Text=The only problem for the city 's craftsmen was that their Free Imperial City ended right behind the city 's walls .
#Text=Unfortunately for them , the mine they depended upon , for the delivery of the ores , was immediately outside these very city walls .
#Text=So they had to lease the rights to the mine from even such regional feudal overlords , the Dukes of Brunswick , who would have fancied it , if the city was theirs .

#Text=This inevitably let to regular skirmishes between the Dukes and their men on the one side , and the burghers on the other side , which were not resolved until the end of the Thirty 's Year War in 1642 AD with the Goslar Accord .
#Text=Goethe 's Goslar Gothic Ghosts
#Text=.

#Text=With the onset of the Reformation in 1517 AD Goslar has escaped the interest of the emperor , and its riches declined so that Goethe , Germany 's national polymath , writes in 1777 during his visit to Goslar : " Imperial City , which rots ' inside ' and ' with ' its privileges !

#Text=Goslar is the Harz region 's festival town , culminating in the annual award of the  Imperial Ring " .

column1: #Text=By plane

#Text=If you own a plane , a helicopter or even a flying saucer then you might wish to land at the club airport Salzgitter-Drütte in the immediate vicinity ( 24 miles ) of Goslar or the Brunswick-Wolfsburg Airport .
#Text=Maybe try the disused military airfield at Goslar itself , but do n't get yourselves into troubles over this .
#Text=However , as a lesser mortal you need to take a plane into either
#Text=Hanover International Airport ( HAJ ) ( 65 miles )
#Text=Leipzig/Halle Airport ( LEJ ) ( 103 miles )
#Text=and make your way to Goslar by car or by train .
#Text=Both airports are connected to the S-Bahn network of their respective cities from where you can take a train to Goslar .
#Text=A further option is flying into Frankfurt Airport ( FRA ) and taking the train from there
#Text=By train
#Text=Goslar can best be accessed by regional trains from Hanover or Brunswick .
#Text=In Hanover and Göttingen there is access to Germany 's ICE ( Inter City Express ) network .
#Text=Getting to other cities might require changes along the way , often in Hildesheim , Salzgitter or Kreiensen .
#Text=By car
#Text=From Paris / London / Brussels / Cologne take the Autobahn A44 /E331 to Kassel and take the A7 /E45 in the direction Hamburg at the Kassel intersection .
#Text=For further directions see below .
#Text=From Madrid / Rome / Vienna / Zurich / Munich / Frankfurt take the A7 /E45 and leave it at either the intersection Seesen .
#Text=Take the Bundesstraße B248 and then the Bundesstraße B82 to Goslar .
#Text=If you wish to take the route via the Harz mountains , exit the A7 /E45 at Northeim and take the Bundesstraße B241 via Osterode , Clausthal-Zellerfeld to Goslar .
#Text=Coming from Moscow / Warsaw / Prague / Berlin , take the A2 /E39 to the intersection Braunschweig and head via the A395 in the direction of Bad Harzburg .
#Text=At Vienenburg you leave the A395 and take the Bundesstraße B241 to Goslar .
#Text=Arriving from Amsterdam / Düsseldorf / Ruhr Basin take the A2 /E39 to Hannover and at the Intersection Hannover leave the A2 /E39 and take the A7 /E45 .
#Text=For further directions , see below .
#Text=Coming from Copenhagen / Stockholm / Oslo / Hamburg / Bremen / Hanover you take the A7 /E45 in the direction Frankfurt .
#Text=You exit the autobahn at Derneburg-Salzgitter ( 63 ) and take the Bundesstraße B6 ( mostly two-lane ) to Goslar or you exit at Rhüden ( 66 ) and take the Bundesstraße B82 to Goslar .
#Text=N.B.
#Text=Goslar is a popular destination for bikers who enjoy riding their bikes through the Harz mountains .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Bus services to and from Goslar are relatively frequent and efficient .
#Text=The regional bus operator Brunswick Regional Transport RBB runs a website , which assists you with finding the relevant connection .
#Text=In Goslar , their hub is in front of the central railway station .
#Text=Here you also find a small travel centre , where staff can provide you with further advise .

#Text=Essentially , the most frequent routes are between Goslar , Seesen , Harzburg-Spa , Salzgitter and Clausthal-Zellerfeld , with less frequent services to other destinations in the Upper Harz ( lines 440 , 450 , 462 , 831 , 838 , 841 , 842 , 850 , 861 , 879 ) .
#Text=The RegioBus lines are the express ones — the others are slow .
#Text=The handy thing is that the RBB forms a partnership with other regional public transport operators , so that you only have to buy a single transferable ticket .
#Text=Thus , there is no need to purchase a new one every time you change your train or bus .
#Text=Regionalbus Braunschweig GmbH
#Text=- Office Goslar , Hildesheimer St. 53 .
